Award.AwardTitle: Towards Mass Balancing Arc Magmatic fluxes - Insights from the Central Mexican Volcanic Belt
Award.AbstractNarration:
Towards mass balancing arc magmatic fluxes - insights from the central Mexican Volcanic Belt

Intellectual Merit: A fundamental breakthrough in understanding the solid Earth geochemical cycle was the recognition of slab recycling in arcs. Quantifying the magnitude of the slab flux, however, is a complex task that requires understanding the petrogenesis of arc magmas, and in particular the causes of their high average SiO2 (>50-65 wt%) by which they differ globally from magmas produced at mid-ocean ridges and intraplate settings. The purpose of this project is to investigate the provenance of high-Si andesites and dacites (=?silicic magmas?) in the central Mexican Volcanic Belt (MVB) from mantle vs. crustal sources. The presence of equilibrium olivines with high, mantle-type 3He/4He (=7-8 Ra) in coeval basaltic and andesitic MVB magmas suggests the possibility that the high-SiO2 melts may have a mantle origin. Studies of silicic volcanic rocks from Quaternary composite volcanoes Malinche,Popocateptl and Nevada de Toluca and from coeval silicic monogenetic volcanoes of The interjacent Sierra Chichinautzin Volcanic Field are proposed to test this idea. Comprehensive major and trace element and isotopic data (incl. Sr-Nd-Pb-Hf isotopes) will be measured in bulk rocks and phenocrysts to evaluate crust vs. mantle contributions to formation of these rocks, and specifically whether or not the silicic magmas are principally(i) crustal partial melts, vs. (ii) melts generated in a subarc mantle infiltrated by reactive silicic fluids and partial melts from the subducting slab. A crustal origin of the silicic magmas would emphasize the importance of intracrustal processing and recycling at the expense of the recycled crustal flux from slab. Confirming the existence of broader spectrum of basaltic to dacitic initial mantle melts in the central MVB, however, has transformative potential as to models of arc magma genesis, arc and continental crustal growth, arc-trench connectivity and hence the overall impact of arc fluxes on the broader geochemical cycles.

Broader Impacts: The project furthers the careers of two female scientists (Straub, with a disability, and Bolge). Participation of undergraduate and graduate students will contribute to the training of the next generation. Scientific interaction between US scientists at Lamont and the Oregon State University and international colleagues in Mexico, Taiwan and Scotland will be furthered. The project proposed is of interest to the broader science community, as it addresses questions on the forefront of the GeoPRISMS Initiative and of the New Science Plan of the post-2013 International Ocean Discovery Program (IODP).

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, we studied the formation of magmas erupting in volcanic arcs. Such arc magmas are unique on Earth. They are more silicic and volatile-rich than magmas produced in other geotectonic settings, and also prone to highly explosive eruptions that pose a constant danger to humankind. Arc magmas form only in so-called 'subduction zones'. These zones are zones of plate collision, where one lithospheric plate - which is a ten of kilometer thick package of crust and underlying mantle - is subducted beneath another plate. Chains of arc volcanoes are constructed on the overriding plate at about 100 km depth above the subducting slab. Thus, arc magma formation may involve material from the overriding plate such as the crustal basement and underlying mantle, as well as from the subducting plate, that is composed of trench sediment, hydrous basaltic oceanic and upper mantle crust. Moreover, crustal basement may become scraped off at the collision front by the overriding plate, and become subducted together with the trench sediment and basaltic crust and fed together with these components into the source region of arc magmas. These scenarios are summarized in Figure 1.

Clearly, it is not easy to trace these individual source components in the arc magmas, as these components are often compositionally similar to each other. However, we were able to discern the eroded crust in the source of the Mexican arc magmas by collecting and testing an extensive suite of geochemical tracers on series of geologically well-constrained arc magmas and on the input materials from various crust and mantle sources. Combined He-O isotopes systematics constrain the arc magmas to be derived from the mantle that contains crustal components recycled from the subducted slab. Combined Nd-Hf isotope and trace element systematics allow for identifying the signals of the eroded frontal crust to be predominant among these slab-derived components. Indeed, the contribution from the eroded crust to the arc magmas is so strong, that the erupted silicic arc magmas may largely be composed of eroded crust. This not only suggests that arc magmas may owe their formation primarily to components recycled from slab (and not newly extracted from mantle), but also that very strong links existed between the subducted slab and arc magmatic fluxes. Thus, our results suggest that the fluxes of solid Earth are more intimately linked with the Earth surface systems (e.g. ocean and atmosphere) than previously perceived.

The results of this project have been published and are of interest for the broader community working on the formation of arc magmas and their role in the broader geochemical cycles (e.g. GeoPRISM and IODP programs). The project was lead by a female PI (with a disability) and included a female co-PI. The project provided training for female undergraduate students (one of an ethnic minority) who used their studies for their senior theses. A Mexican-based Columbian graduate student participated in the field work. A visiting Mexican laboratory technicial specalist learnt Hf separation for isotope chemistry at Lamont. Furthermore, the project fostered collaboration with among scientists from two US institutions (Lamont and University of Eugene, Oregon), and with international colleagues from Mexico, Scotland, England, Australia, New Zealand and Taiwan.
